 Being immersed in discrimination from birth and accepting it is difficult to shake. I spent enough time in Southern US states around well educated and traveled individuals and those without that exposure to understand it generally takes a permanent change of peer groups and geography for most to change their root beliefs. It can be likened to religion in the sense of closed minds associating only with other closed minds for intellectual exposure and assimilation response.

 I don't really know anything about them and their family, except the articles that I've read about their music and their racist beliefs, but I seriously doubt that they would end up going to University... that is purely a guess but people who hate so many others for no reason tend to be very ignorant.
 
 I feel bad for them, because although they are so wrong, it's just the way they've been brought up-- and I don't think that they're going to change...

"It really breaks my heart to see those two girls spewing out that kind of garbage," said Ted Shaw, civil rights advocate and president of the NAACP's Legal Defense Fund - though Shaw points out that the girls aren't espousing their own opinions but ones they're being taught.

 
 I wonder whether he believes that no 13 year old has opinions, or whether this is reserved for racists?
 
 There is a hope they'll grow out of it: after all, the decline in racism suggests racists have non-racist children. If they go to college it might help, both in terms of education and mixing with mixed race groups.
